Dear Ms. Carter:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
November 7, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed or
implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis,

Ten of ten new employees did not have a CWL-4624 run prior to hire. All ten
employees had a CWL-1910 record in their employee file, but this does not meet
the CRC requirement established in November 2022. In addition, two of the ten
new employees had their central registry checks completed over 30 days prior to
hire. One new employee was hired on 10/30/23, but the CWL-1910 was completed
on 9/19/23. Another new employee was hired on 1/9/23, but the CWL-1920 was
completed on 12/1/22.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance regarding the process and timeframes for
completion of central registry requests for staff prior to hire and annually. The facility
was provided the CWL-4624, FAQ, communication issuances and an email explanation
to assist the facility in developing an appropriate process.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not require any consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The first CAP was approved on 12/8/22 and was a result of a violation found in SIR
2023C0000009 dated 11/17/22. The facility demonstrated compliance with their
CAP by implementing increased supervision procedures for youth, increased
training for staff, increased support for staff, and ongoing conversations about
youth supervision in individual supervision meetings as well as team meetings.
The second CAP was approved on 12/14/22 and was a result of violations found in
the facility's Renewal Inspection Report approved on 11/29/22. The facility
demonstrated full compliance with their CAP by having youth/families sign
verification they were provided the grievance policy during intake, and tracking to
ensure youth will receive an initial physical exam if they reside at the facility for
more than 21 days.
3

Financial Overview
The facility's financial audit and budget were reviewed. There were no concerns
noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not applicable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) noted the facility has been in substantial compliance with
DHHS licensing rules. CA reported they fully implemented both of their CAPs
during the period of review, and successfully completed both. CA noted unplanned
discharges continue to be difficult to assess due to the voluntary nature of the
program. CA reported the leadership team and programming staff will continue to
conduct quarterly chart audits, program inspections, and team meetings to review
and ensure continued compliance with licensing rules.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed reported their coworkers, management and the youth are
awesome. They reported they love there's something new and different every day.
They love the opportunity to make a positive impact on youths' lives in such a short
period of time. They reported they were without a supervisor for a year, and
although the Chief Administrator and Clinical Manager did an amazing job
supporting and training them, they like that they have a supervisor and feel there's
a chain of command in place now. Staff reported support and training has
significantly improved over the last year, which has made everyone feel more
comfortable with their duties and has made them closer as a "work family". Staff
reported they are in the process of creating a new training guide, which will be
more hands-on and will make onboarding new staff more effective and efficient.
Staff reported recently the facility changed staff schedules around so there is now
one full-time staff member on each shift, which provides more consistency and
structure. Staff reported everyone is working hard and teaming together to build the
program to the best it can be. Staff reported another big improvement has been an
increase in youth accountability and responsibility. Staff reported a few areas of
continued growth and improvement include continuing to empower staff to make
decisions independently, continue to work on and train de-escalation skills, and
hiring more staff members for swing shifts.
Youth interviewed reported they love staying at The Bridge because it is amazing.
They reported the facility is not strict, but it is structured, which is really nice. They
reported the staff are awesome, very supportive, and very nice. They reported they
enjoy having house meetings, and feel any issues brought up during those
meetings, or outside of those meetings, are addressed timely and thoroughly. They
also reported the meals are amazing and the facility is always clean.
Description of Agency Walk Through
4

A walkthrough of the facility was completed on November 7, 2023. The facility was
clean and in good condition. There were no safety concerns.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
